items.title: U.S. launches military strikes on Venezuela, Trump says Maduro captured
items.standfirst: Soon after the U.S. carried out military strikes inside Venezuela, President Trump said the nation's President Nicolás Maduro had been captured and flown out.
items.content: Soon after the U.S. carried out military strikes inside Venezuela, President Trump said the nation's President Nicolás Maduro had been captured and flown out.

items.title: Venezuelan president Maduro captured and flown out of country following ‘large scale’ US attack, Trump says – live
items.standfirst: US president says ‘the United States of America has successfully carried out a large scale strike against Venezuela’Full report: Trump confirms attack on Venezuela and says Maduro capturedThe Reuters news agency says it has been told by a US official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, that the US carried out strikes inside Venezuela on Saturday.The unnamed official did not provide details. As mentioned earlier, the White House and Pentagon did not immediately respond to request for comment on Saturday morning. Continue reading...
items.content: US president says ‘the United States of America has successfully carried out a large scale strike against Venezuela’Full report: Trump confirms attack on Venezuela and says Maduro capturedThe Reuters news agency says it has been told by a US official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, that the US carried out strikes inside Venezuela on Saturday.The unnamed official did not provide details. As mentioned earlier, the White House and Pentagon did not immediately respond to request for comment on Saturday morning. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says Nicolás Maduro has been captured and flown out of Venezuela

items.title: Venezuela: Trump says "Maduro has been captured and flown out" of the country
items.standfirst: The Venezuelan government on Saturday demanded "immediate proof of life" of President Nicolas Maduro and his wife Cilia Flores after the US announced he had been captured and taken out of the country. Maduro's whereabouts remain unknown after the US conducted a "large-scale strike" earlier in the day with multiple explosions and aircraft-like sounds reported across the capital Caracas. Member of the Sciences Po's Political Observatory of Latin America, Eduardo Rios, and journalist Noris Argotte Sodo, explain further.
items.content: The Venezuelan government on Saturday demanded "immediate proof of life" of President Nicolas Maduro and his wife Cilia Flores after the US announced he had been captured and taken out of the country. Maduro's whereabouts remain unknown after the US conducted a "large-scale strike" earlier in the day with multiple explosions and aircraft-like sounds reported across the capital Caracas. Member of the Sciences Po's Political Observatory of Latin America, Eduardo Rios, and journalist Noris Argotte Sodo, explain further.

items.title: Trump claims US has captured Venezuelan dictator and wife
items.standfirst: US president says on social media that operation to capture Nicolás Maduro carried out with US law enforcementTrump confirms US attack on Venezuela: latest news updatesDonald Trump has claimed the US has “captured” Venezuela’s dictator, Nicolás Maduro, and his wife, Cilia Flores, and flown them out of the South American country after a pre-dawn assault on Caracas and the surrounding region.“It was a brilliant operation, actually,” the US president told the New York Times after eyewitnesses in Venezuela reported a series of explosions. “A lot of good planning and [a] lot of great, great troops and great people.” Continue reading...
items.content: US president says on social media that operation to capture Nicolás Maduro carried out with US law enforcementTrump confirms US attack on Venezuela: latest news updatesDonald Trump has claimed the US has “captured” Venezuela’s dictator, Nicolás Maduro, and his wife, Cilia Flores, and flown them out of the South American country after a pre-dawn assault on Caracas and the surrounding region.“It was a brilliant operation, actually,” the US president told the New York Times after eyewitnesses in Venezuela reported a series of explosions. “A lot of good planning and [a] lot of great, great troops and great people.” Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says Maduro 'captured and flown out' of Venezuela
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump announced on Saturday that Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro has been captured after the US conducted a "large-scale strike" on the country. Maduro had declared a state of emergency earlier in the day, accusing the United States of a “very serious military aggression” after multiple explosions and aircraft-like sounds were reported across the capital Caracas. France24 journalist Shirli Sitbon explains further.
items.content: US President Donald Trump announced on Saturday that Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro has been captured after the US conducted a "large-scale strike" on the country. Maduro had declared a state of emergency earlier in the day, accusing the United States of a “very serious military aggression” after multiple explosions and aircraft-like sounds were reported across the capital Caracas. France24 journalist Shirli Sitbon explains further.

items.title: What we know about US strikes on Venezuela as Maduro 'captured'
items.standfirst: The US has carried out a "large-scale strike" against Venezuela, and its leader, Nicolas Maduro, has been flown out of the country with his wife.
items.content: The US has carried out a "large-scale strike" against Venezuela, and its leader, Nicolas Maduro, has been flown out of the country with his wife.

items.title: US launches military strikes on Venezuela after Trump's threats against Maduro
items.standfirst: Venezuela has accused the United States of launching attacks after a series of explosions struck Caracas and other regions, prompting President Nicolás Maduro to say his government had repelled what he called U.S. military aggression and to declare a state of emergency. The blasts were reported around 2 a.m. local time, accompanied by the sound of aircraft overhead, with smoke seen rising from a military base hangar and power outages affecting parts of the capital. U.S. officials told Reuters that American forces were conducting strikes inside Venezuela, amid an expanded U.S. military presence in the region aimed at intercepting alleged drug trafficking vessels linked to the country. Washington Bureau Chief at The Guardian, David Smith, tells us more.
items.content: Venezuela has accused the United States of launching attacks after a series of explosions struck Caracas and other regions, prompting President Nicolás Maduro to say his government had repelled what he called U.S. military aggression and to declare a state of emergency. The blasts were reported around 2 a.m. local time, accompanied by the sound of aircraft overhead, with smoke seen rising from a military base hangar and power outages affecting parts of the capital. U.S. officials told Reuters that American forces were conducting strikes inside Venezuela, amid an expanded U.S. military presence in the region aimed at intercepting alleged drug trafficking vessels linked to the country. Washington Bureau Chief at The Guardian, David Smith, tells us more.

Maduro had declared a state of emergency earlier in the day, accusing the United States of a “very serious military aggression” after multiple explosions and aircraft-like sounds were reported across the capital Caracas. Noris Argotte Soto reports from Caracas.
items.content: US President Donald Trump announced on Saturday that Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro has been captured after the US conducted a "large-scale strike" on the country. Maduro had declared a state of emergency earlier in the day, accusing the United States of a “very serious military aggression” after multiple explosions and aircraft-like sounds were reported across the capital Caracas. clusters.title: Crans-Montana: About 40 killed, 119 injured in fire
clusters.neutral_headline: Swiss bar fire likely started by sparklers on champagne bottles

items.title: Crans-Montana: About 40 killed, 119 injured in fire
items.standfirst: As Switzerland mourns, authorities are continuing to investigate the cause of the deadly fire and now believe it was triggered by sparklers placed on champagne bottles that came too close to the bar’s ceiling. Investigators are also examining whether the venue’s materials met fire safety regulations. Meanwhile, families anxiously await news of their loved ones, as some victims have been transferred to specialized burn units in hospitals in France and Italy, while six people remain unidentified. Simon Mortiz and Valériane Gauthier have more.
items.content: As Switzerland mourns, authorities are continuing to investigate the cause of the deadly fire and now believe it was triggered by sparklers placed on champagne bottles that came too close to the bar’s ceiling. Investigators are also examining whether the venue’s materials met fire safety regulations. Meanwhile, families anxiously await news of their loved ones, as some victims have been transferred to specialized burn units in hospitals in France and Italy, while six people remain unidentified. Simon Mortiz and Valériane Gauthier have more.

items.title: Switzerland: Investigators examine nightclub fire origin sparkler link
items.standfirst: As Switzerland mourns, authorities are continuing to investigate the cause of the deadly fire and now believe it was triggered by sparklers placed on champagne bottles that came too close to the bar’s ceiling. Investigators are also examining whether the venue’s materials met fire safety regulations. Meanwhile, families anxiously await news of their loved ones, as some victims have been transferred to specialized burn units in hospitals in France and Italy, while six people remain unidentified. France24 journalist Olivia Bizot reports the latest from Crans-Montana.
items.content: As Switzerland mourns, authorities are continuing to investigate the cause of the deadly fire and now believe it was triggered by sparklers placed on champagne bottles that came too close to the bar’s ceiling. Investigators are also examining whether the venue’s materials met fire safety regulations. Meanwhile, families anxiously await news of their loved ones, as some victims have been transferred to specialized burn units in hospitals in France and Italy, while six people remain unidentified. items.title: Swiss bar fire started by sparklers, investigators say, amid efforts to ID victims
items.standfirst: Many of those killed and injured by a fire that tore through a bar in Switzerland's Crans-Montana ski resort were teenagers celebrating the new year.
items.content: Many of those killed and injured by a fire that tore through a bar in Switzerland's Crans-Montana ski resort were teenagers celebrating the new year.

items.title: Sparklers likely caused deadly inferno at Swiss ski resort, investigators say
items.standfirst: Investigators said that the deadly fire that tore through a popular bar in the Swiss ski resort of Crans-Montana early on New Year's Day was caused by sparklers on Champagne bottles, which ignited the bar's ceiling. Ramy Inocencio reports.
items.content: Investigators said that the deadly fire that tore through a popular bar in the Swiss ski resort of Crans-Montana early on New Year's Day was caused by sparklers on Champagne bottles, which ignited the bar's ceiling. Ramy Inocencio reports.

items.title: Swiss bar fire likely started by sparklers on champagne bottles
items.standfirst: The investigation into the fire that killed 40 people will consider whether criminal prosecutions are necessary, officials said.
items.content: The investigation into the fire that killed 40 people will consider whether criminal prosecutions are necessary, officials said.

items.title: Swiss bar fire was like 'hell': Survivors recount ski resort blaze
items.standfirst: CRANS-MONTANA, Switzerland — Ringing in the new year with a night of drinking and dancing high in the Swiss Alps, Ebenezer Mehari, 17, decided to take a breather outside the packed Constellation Bar
items.content: CRANS-MONTANA, Switzerland — Ringing in the new year with a night of drinking and dancing high in the Swiss Alps, Ebenezer Mehari, 17, decided to take a breather outside the packed Constellation Bar

items.title: Switzerland resort fire ‘likely started by sparklers in champagne bottles’, says attorney general – as it happened
items.standfirst: Officials say 40 people were killed and 119 injured, with some in hospital still unidentified due to ‘horrific’ injuriesItaly’s ambassador to Switzerland Gian Lorenzo Cornado has said that all bar five of the 112 injured have been identified now, reports Reuters. Swiss officials are yet to give an update on this and have not shared the names of any victims or injured.Six Italians are still missing and 13 hospitalised, he added. Three Italians were repatriated on Thursday and three more will follow on Friday, he said.It’s the grief, as if we have all lost a loved one. Continue reading...
items.content: Officials say 40 people were killed and 119 injured, with some in hospital still unidentified due to ‘horrific’ injuriesItaly’s ambassador to Switzerland Gian Lorenzo Cornado has said that all bar five of the 112 injured have been identified now, reports Reuters. Swiss officials are yet to give an update on this and have not shared the names of any victims or injured.Six Italians are still missing and 13 hospitalised, he added. Three Italians were repatriated on Thursday and three more will follow on Friday, he said.It’s the grief, as if we have all lost a loved one. Continue reading...

items.title: Sparklers held near ceiling started Swiss ski resort fire, investigators believe
items.standfirst: Footage and witness statements show blaze that killed about 40 was ‘very rapid’, prosecutor saysInvestigators believe fountain sparklers mounted on champagne bottles and held too close to the ceiling sparked the deadly fire that tore through a crowded bar in the ski resort of Crans-Montana, killing about 40 people and injuring more than 100.“Everything suggests the fire started from the burning candles or ‘Bengal lights’ that had been attached to champagne bottles,” the prosecutor Béatrice Pilloud said on Friday. “These went too close to the ceiling.” Continue reading...
items.content: Footage and witness statements show blaze that killed about 40 was ‘very rapid’, prosecutor saysInvestigators believe fountain sparklers mounted on champagne bottles and held too close to the ceiling sparked the deadly fire that tore through a crowded bar in the ski resort of Crans-Montana, killing about 40 people and injuring more than 100.“Everything suggests the fire started from the burning candles or ‘Bengal lights’ that had been attached to champagne bottles,” the prosecutor Béatrice Pilloud said on Friday. “These went too close to the ceiling.” Continue reading...

items.title: Saudi invites Yemen’s southern factions to ‘dialogue’ in Riyadh after surprise independence bid
items.standfirst: Southern Transitional Council wants to form a breakaway state, which would split the Arabian Peninsula’s poorest state in twoSaudi Arabia’s foreign ministry has called for Yemen’s southern factions to attend a “dialogue” in Riyadh, after a surprise independence bid and the United Arab Emirates declaring it had withdrawn all troops from Yemen.In a statement on Saturday, the Saudi ministry urged “a comprehensive conference in Riyadh to bring together all southern factions to discuss just solutions to the southern cause”. Riyadh said the Yemeni government had issued the invitation for talks. Continue reading...
items.content: Southern Transitional Council wants to form a breakaway state, which would split the Arabian Peninsula’s poorest state in twoSaudi Arabia’s foreign ministry has called for Yemen’s southern factions to attend a “dialogue” in Riyadh, after a surprise independence bid and the United Arab Emirates declaring it had withdrawn all troops from Yemen.In a statement on Saturday, the Saudi ministry urged “a comprehensive conference in Riyadh to bring together all southern factions to discuss just solutions to the southern cause”. Riyadh said the Yemeni government had issued the invitation for talks. Continue reading...

clusters.title: India: Contamined water blamed as diarrhoea outbreak kills 10 in Indore
clusters.neutral_headline: Indian families grieve deaths caused by contaminated tap water

items.title: India: Contamined water blamed as diarrhoea outbreak kills 10 in Indore
items.standfirst: At least 10 people have died and more than 250 others have been hospitalized in a diarrhoea outbreak in the central Indian city of Indore, according to local health officials, who say the illness was caused by contaminated drinking water. Residents have complained that authorities have failed to address longstanding problems with the sewage system, which they believe contributed to the outbreak. Peter O'Brien tells us more.
items.content: At least 10 people have died and more than 250 others have been hospitalized in a diarrhoea outbreak in the central Indian city of Indore, according to local health officials, who say the illness was caused by contaminated drinking water. Residents have complained that authorities have failed to address longstanding problems with the sewage system, which they believe contributed to the outbreak. Peter O'Brien tells us more.

items.title: Sewage in drinking water blamed for at least 10 deaths in India’s ‘cleanest city’
items.standfirst: Hundreds hospitalised in Indore after public toilet built above water pipeline appears to have let sewage into supplySewage-contaminated drinking water is being blamed for killing at least 10 people, including a baby boy, and sending more than 270 others to hospital in Indore, ranked India’s “cleanest city” for the last eight years.Residents of a congested, lower-income neighbourhood in Indore, Madhya Pradesh’s commercial capital, had been warning authorities for months about foul-smelling tap water. Their complaints went unheeded, despite the city’s much-lauded ranking for waste segregation and other cleanliness measures. Continue reading...
items.content: Hundreds hospitalised in Indore after public toilet built above water pipeline appears to have let sewage into supplySewage-contaminated drinking water is being blamed for killing at least 10 people, including a baby boy, and sending more than 270 others to hospital in Indore, ranked India’s “cleanest city” for the last eight years.Residents of a congested, lower-income neighbourhood in Indore, Madhya Pradesh’s commercial capital, had been warning authorities for months about foul-smelling tap water. Their complaints went unheeded, despite the city’s much-lauded ranking for waste segregation and other cleanliness measures. Continue reading...

items.content: Officials in Indore say four people have died after drinking contaminated water but families allege the toll is higher.

clusters.title: Ukraine hosts security talks in Kyiv after strike hit Kharkiv on Friday
clusters.neutral_headline: Zelensky names spy chief to head presidential office after corruption row

items.title: Ukraine hosts security talks in Kyiv after strike hit Kharkiv on Friday
items.standfirst: As the war in Ukraine enters the new year, Russian bombardments continue to hit Ukrainian cities, with authorities reporting on Friday that residential areas in Kharkiv were targeted. Amid Russia’s largest battlefield gains since 2022, Ukraine has ordered the evacuation of 3,000 children from the Dnipro and Zaporizhia regions. Caroline Baum reports.
items.content: As the war in Ukraine enters the new year, Russian bombardments continue to hit Ukrainian cities, with authorities reporting on Friday that residential areas in Kharkiv were targeted. Amid Russia’s largest battlefield gains since 2022, Ukraine has ordered the evacuation of 3,000 children from the Dnipro and Zaporizhia regions. Caroline Baum reports.

items.title: Zelensky names spy boss chief to head presidential administration in big shakeup
items.standfirst: President Volodymyr Zelenskiy named Ukraine's military intelligence chief Kyrylo Budanov as his top adviser on Friday and proposed a drone and digitalisation specialist as defence minister. The appointments were made as Kyiv seeks to strengthen its hand in U.S.-backed talks to end its nearly four-year-old conflict with Russia. France24 correspondent from Ukraine, Emmanuele Chaze, tells us the latest.
items.content: President Volodymyr Zelenskiy named Ukraine's military intelligence chief Kyrylo Budanov as his top adviser on Friday and proposed a drone and digitalisation specialist as defence minister. The appointments were made as Kyiv seeks to strengthen its hand in U.S.-backed talks to end its nearly four-year-old conflict with Russia. France24 correspondent from Ukraine, Emmanuele Chaze, tells us the latest.

items.title: Zelensky names spy chief to head presidential office after corruption row
items.standfirst: Kyrylo Budanov has led the Hur military intelligence, which has claimed a number of highly-effective strikes against Russia.
items.content: Kyrylo Budanov has led the Hur military intelligence, which has claimed a number of highly-effective strikes against Russia.

items.title: Ukraine's Zelensky names spy chief Kyrylo Budanov as new top aide
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Friday appointed military intelligence chief Kyrylo Budanov as head of his office, following the resignation of top aide Andriy Yermak over a corruption scandal. Budanov, credited with daring operations against Russia, will focus on security, defence and diplomatic efforts amid the ongoing war.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Friday appointed military intelligence chief Kyrylo Budanov as head of his office, following the resignation of top aide Andriy Yermak over a corruption scandal. Budanov, credited with daring operations against Russia, will focus on security, defence and diplomatic efforts amid the ongoing war.

items.title: Russia makes largest territorial gains in Ukraine since 2022 invasion
items.standfirst: Russia captured more than 5,600 sq km of Ukrainian territory in 2025, its largest advance since 2022, as Kyiv prepares to host allied security talks. As pressure on the battlefield continues to build, President Volodymyr Zelensky named Kyrylo Budanov his new top aide, proposed Mykhailo Fedorov as defence minister and ordered the evacuation of thousands from frontline settlements.
items.content: Russia captured more than 5,600 sq km of Ukrainian territory in 2025, its largest advance since 2022, as Kyiv prepares to host allied security talks. As pressure on the battlefield continues to build, President Volodymyr Zelensky named Kyrylo Budanov his new top aide, proposed Mykhailo Fedorov as defence minister and ordered the evacuation of thousands from frontline settlements.

items.title: ‘Sunshine Saturday’: UK firms expect 5% January rise in holiday bookings
items.standfirst: Quieter destinations, such as Malta’s sister island, Gozo, and long-haul locations are expected to be popularUK travel companies are bracing for one of their busiest periods for bookings as winter-wearied consumers plan sunny breaks, with package holiday bookings forecast to be up 5% this January.The Civil Aviation Authority, the regulator that administers the Atol travel financial protection scheme, has forecast that 200,000 more holidaymakers will book trips this month compared with the 4.3 million who did so in the same period last year. Continue reading...

items.title: Reddit overtakes TikTok in UK thanks to search algorithms and gen Z
items.standfirst: Platform is now Britain’s fourth most visited social media site as users seek out human-generated contentReddit, the online discussion platform, has overtaken TikTok as Britain’s fourth most visited social media service, as search algorithms and gen Z have dramatically transformed its prominence.The platform has undergone huge growth over the last two years, with an 88% increase in the proportion of UK internet users it reaches. Three in five Brits online now encounter the site, up from a third in 2023, according to Ofcom. Continue reading...
items.content: Platform is now Britain’s fourth most visited social media site as users seek out human-generated contentReddit, the online discussion platform, has overtaken TikTok as Britain’s fourth most visited social media service, as search algorithms and gen Z have dramatically transformed its prominence.The platform has undergone huge growth over the last two years, with an 88% increase in the proportion of UK internet users it reaches. Three in five Brits online now encounter the site, up from a third in 2023, according to Ofcom. Continue reading...

items.title: Saks Global CEO steps down as luxury retailer reportedly preparing for bankruptcy
items.standfirst: Executive chair Richard Baker to replace Marc Metrick after company misses $100m interest payment on debtSaks Global said on Friday that its CEO, Marc Metrick, has stepped down and named executive chair, Richard Baker, as his successor, amid reports that the luxury retailer is preparing for bankruptcy.The change at the top comes days after the Wall Street Journal reported that the Neiman Marcus parent company is preparing for bankruptcy after missing an interest payment exceeding $100m on debt from its Neiman merger. items.title: Potential terror attack inspired by ISIS thwarted in North Carolina, officials say
items.standfirst: A potential New Year's Eve terror attack inspired by ISIS was thwarted in North Carolina, authorities announced. A suspect is in custody, accused of planning to attack a grocery store and a fast food restaurant in the town of Mint Hill, which is located near Charlotte. Scott MacFarlane has the latest.
